questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric ward. Height of the child was <3rd percentile according to growth charts. On further examination his upper segment: lower segment ratio (US:LS) was found to be not normal. Which of the following condition explains the above scenario?
questions.explanation:
Short trunk dwarfism (US: LS Decreases) Short Limb Dwarfism (US: LS Increases)
  • Mnemonic: “Short Man May Climb High”
  • Spondylo-Epiphyseal Dysplasia
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis
  • Mucolipidosis
  • Caries spine (Pott’s disease)
  • Vertebral defects like hemivertebrae, butterfly vertebrae etc.
  • seen in Alagille syndrome
  • triangular facies (also seen in Russell Silver syndrome)
  • butterfly vertebra
  • pulmonary stenosis
  • cholestatic jaundice
  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta
  • Congenital Hypothyroidism

questions.text: A child was bought to the pediatric ward. The child had jargon speech and could point towards object. What will be the estimated age according to milestone?
questions.explanation:
AGE Important Language Milestones
6 months Monosyllable speech (speaks 'ma', 'ba', 'da')
9 months Speaks bisyllables eg mama, papa, but without meaning
12 months Speaks 2-3 words with meaning; Imitates simple sounds;
15 months Jargon speech
18 months Knows 10 words with meaning
2 years 2 word sentences; Vocabulary of 100 words; Uses pronouns like 'I', 'me', 'you'
3 years 3 word sentences; Uses plurals & past tense; Repeats 3 digits;
4 years Tells a story / poem / sings a song

Age Important Social Milestones
2 months Social smile
3 months Recognizes mother
6 months Smiles at mirror image ('Mirror play')
7 months Stranger anxiety
8 months Object permanence
9 months Waves bye bye
10 months Plays peek-a-boo
12 months Kisses on request; Plays a simple ball game;
15 months Points to objects; Indicates wet pants;
18 months Domestic mimicry; Dry during daytime (bladder control at day)
2 years Parallel play
3 years Joins in play; Knows name, age & gender; Dry during night;

questions.text: A newborn child had respiratory distress and scaphoid abdomen. On chest Xray mediastinal shift and pulmonary hypoplasia was noted. Which of the following is not a predictor of poor outcome of this condition?

Match the following? I. Dry submarine a) Tying of a plastic bag over the head II. Black slave b) Head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrists bound to the ankle III. Sawhorse c) Heated metal skewer inserted into the anus IV. Parrot's perch d) Forced straddling of a bar
Which of the following are part of the bullet of a rifled gun? Primer Gun Powder Ward
questions.explanation:
Shot gun cartridge Rifle gun bullet
  • Primer (highly inflammable)
  • Gun powder
  • Wad
  • Lead Shots
  • Primer
  • Gun Powder
  • Bullet
  • NO WAD in Rifled Gun.

questions.text: During performing an autopsy inflow outflow method of heart-dissection. Which heart chamber was dissected into first?
questions.explanation:
Autopsy Techniques Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed"en masse," as one big organ block.
  • The best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other
  • Rapid technique
 Difficult to handle large mass.
Ghon’s Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks(en block) This method can also be used in Infants
Virchow’s Organs are removedone by one Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Anatomical relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situdissection (inside the body itself)

Good for

  • infected bodies like HIV, Hepatitis B (prevents spreading of infection)
  • Radiation hazards
  • Fetal brain dissection

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about embalming?

options.label: A
options.text: Best when done within 6 hrs of death

options.label: B
options.text: Best method: Discontinuous injection and drainage

options.label: D
options.text: Artificial method of preservation of dead body by injecting embalming fluid

questions.correct_answer: C. Ethanol is used in Embalming.

Age group Preferred 1st line ART regimen
Infant <2 weeks Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Nevirapine
Children <3 years Abacavir (or Zidovudine) + Lamivudine + Lopinavir / Ritonavir
Children 3-10 years Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
Adolescents Tenofovir + Lamivudine (or Emtricitabine) + Efavirenz

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false?

options.label: A
options.text: S cells secretes SECRETIN - Constricts the pyloric sphincter. Causes secretion of HCO3 rich pancreatic

options.label: B
options.text: I CELLS Secrets CCK – ↑Gastric motility ↓Intestinal motility

questions.correct_answer: B. I CELLS Secrets CCK – ↑Gastric motility ↓Intestinal motility
questions.explanation:
1. S cells secrete SECRET IN (1st hormone to be discovered)
  • Stimulated by acidic chyme.
  • Maintains alkaline pH in the duodenum
  • Constricts the pyloric sphincter. Causes secretion of HCO3 rich pancreatic
2. I CELLS Secrets CCK *Stimulated by fat breakdown products
  • ↓gastric motility

↑intestinal motility

Causes enzyme-rich pancreatic juice to be secreted bile flow from gall bladder (cholagogue)
3. M0 CELLS secrets MOTILIN
  • ↑MMC contraction

questions.text: Pick the false statement out of the following:

options.label: C
options.text: SPINNBARKEIT (Elasticity) →mucus dries in an arborising / fern-like pattern

questions.text: A patient had gone for MRI and was diagnosed with DCIS. On physical examination it was concluded that it was not palpable. What will be the best next step for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Excision by needle localization with specimen mammography

questions.correct_answer: A. Excision by needle localization with specimen mammography

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with breast cancer. The size of tumor was determined to be 6cm and satellite nodules presence was reported. Ipsilateral axillary lymph node involvement which are fixed. What will be the staging this Cancer?
questions.explanation:
Stage Size of tumor
T1 up to 2 cm
T2 2-5cm
T3 >5cm
T4a

Extension to chest wall (chest wall is formed by Ribs, Intercostal muscles, Serratus Anterior)

  • Ulceration
T4b
  • edema including Peau-D-Orange
  • Satellite nodules
T4c T4a + T4b
T4d Inflammatory breast cancer
Lymph node (N) Staging
N1
  • Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary lymph node level I and II
  • Mobile
N2a
  • Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary LN I and II
  • Fixed / matted lymph nodes
N2b
  • Metastasis only in ipsilateral internal mammary nodes in the absence of axillary lymph node metastases
N3a
  • Metastasis to ipsilateral infraclavicular LN
N3b
  • Metastasis to ipsilateral axillary + internal mammary LN
N3c
  • Metastasis to ipsilateral supraclavicular LN

Stage I T1
Stage IIA T0-1 N1 T2
Stage IIB T2 N1
T3
Stage IIIA T0-2 N2
T3 N1-2
Stage IIIB T4 N0-2
Stage IIIC T any N3
Stage IV T any N any M1

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of post sinusoidal extrahepatic cause of portal hypertension?

Match the following: 1. Type I a) Paraesophageal hernia with herniation of content other than stomach 2. Type II b) Herniation of both GE junction of fundus of stomach 3. Type III c) Herniation of GE junction 4. Type IV d) Herniation of fundus of stomach
questions.explanation:
Type I
  • Aka sliding hernia (most common type)
  • Herniation of GE junction
Type II
  • Aka true Paraesophageal hernia (Rolling Hernia)
  • Herniation of fundus of stomach
  • GE junction located below diaphragm
Type III
  • Aka mixed Paraesophageal hernia (sliding + rolling hernia)
  • Herniation of both GE junction of fundus of stomach
Type IV
  • Paraesophageal hernia with herniation of content other than stomach

questions.text: According to Modified Johnson’s Classification which of the following is associated with Type ‘A’ Blood group the given type of ulcers?

options.text: Ulcers located higher on lesser curvature

Modified Johnson’s classification
Type I Ulcer located at incisura Angularis
Type II

Two ulcers:

  • One in body of stomach
  • One at 1st part of duodenum
Type III

Aka prepyloric ulcer

  • Ulcer located just before pylorus
Type IV Ulcer located higher on lesser curvature
Type V NSAIDS induced ulcers

PURINE PYRIMIDINE
N1 - Aspartate N1 - Aspartate
N3 N9 - Glutamine N3 - Glutamine
C4, C5 and N7 - Glycine C4, C5 and C6 - Aspartate

C6 - CO2

C2 and C8 - THF

Extra CH3 - THF
C1 of sugar is joined with N9 of purine but N1 of pyrimidines in nucleoside by Beta-N-glycosidic bond

Live vaccines BCG, OPV, Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Yellow fever vaccine, Varicella, Typhoral, JE live vaccine, H1N1 live, Rotaviral vaccine

questions.explanation:
HOCKEY STICK SIGNS
ECG

Digoxin effect
Echocardiography

Mitral stenosis

  • Normal, biphasic, and rapid motion of the mitral valve is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering results in a "hockey stick" appearance.
  • These changes obstruct the blood flow from the atrium to the ventricle
MRI Brain

Hockey-stick sign of v CJD

  • FLAIR image shows symmetrical pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclear hyperintensity.
  • This combination gives a characteristic "hockey-stick" appearance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a coal mining factory for 27 years develops symptoms of progressively worsening breathlessness and cough with expectoration. On an ABG, pH of 7.2, pO2of 46, pCO2of 80 are indicative of:
Which of the following vasculitis is seen in childhood? Kawasaki HSP Susac syndrome Giant cell
questions.explanation:
Disease in choice Age of presentation and findings
Kawasaki Occurs predominantly in young children; 80% of patients are<5 yr., and, only occasionally, are teenagers or, more rarely, adults affected.
HSP Usually seen in children; most patients range inage from 4 to 7 years; however, the disease may also be seen in infants and adults.
Susac's Syndrome Consists of thetriad of encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusions (BRAO), and hearing loss. It usually affects women aged 20 to 40, but men are also affected, and the age range extends from 9 to 72 years
Giant Cell Arteritis Occurs almost exclusively in individuals >50 year

LCB stained periorbital exudates in severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis in an elderly diabetic shows obtuse-angled branching aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Option 1 Candida: Yeastlikefungi.
Option 2

Aspergillus: Narrowseptatehyaline hyphae withacute anglebranching molds.
Option 3 Penicillium: Hyaline thinseptatehyphae, vesicles are absent, and conidia arranged asbrush border appearance molds.
Option 4

Points in favor of Rhizopus:

→non-septatebroad hyphae

→Obtuseangled branching

→ Forms asexual spores: sporangia

→ sexual spores → Zygospores

  • Zygomycota are aseptate fungi that cause serious infections, primarily in ketoacidotic diabetic patients and cancer patients.

2.Agents of Zygomycosis

  • Rhizopus
  • Mucor
  • Absidia
  • Apophysomyces

3.Rhizoid’s arrangement

  • No rhizoids: Mucor
  • Internodal arrangement: Absidia
  • Directly opposite to sporangia: Rhizopus

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is correct regarding the use of tocolytics in case of preterm labor?

    • Deceleration phase

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Laboratory criteria of APLA Syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Lupus anticoagulant positivity on >2 occasions at least 12 weeks apart.

options.label: B
options.text: Anticardiolipin antibody titer medium or higher on 2 or more occasions.

options.label: C
options.text: Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein-I antibody in medium or high titer on 2 or more occasions 12 weeks apart.

questions.explanation:
Clinical criteria
  • Vascular thrombosis: ≥1 arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    • ≥1 fetal death (at or beyond the 10th week of gestation)
    • ≥1 premature birth before the 34th week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    • ≥3 consecutive (pre) embryonic losses (before the 10th week of gestation)
Laboratory criteria
  • Lupus anticoagulant positivity on ≥ 2 occasions at least 12 weeks apart
  • Anticardiolipin antibody (IgG and /or IgM) in medium or high titer (i.e > 40, or above the 99th percentile), on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart
  • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein –I antibody (IgG and /or IgM) in medium or high titer (ie, above the 99th percentile) on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart

Group -1- minimal risk

Atrial septal defect

Ventricular septal defect

Patent ductusarteriosus

Pulmonic or tricuspid disease

Fallot tetralogy, corrected

Bioprosthetic valve

Mitral stenosis, NYHA classes 1 and 2

 0-1

Group 2- moderated risk Mitralstenosis, NYHA classes III and IV Aortic stenosis

Aortic coarctation without valvular involvement Fallot tetralogy, uncorrected Previous myocardial infarction

Marfan syndrome, normal aorta Mitralstenosis with atrial fibrillation Artificial valve

 5-15

Group 3 – Major risk Pulmonary hypertension (primary and secondary)

Aortic coarctation with valvular involvement

Marfan syndrome with aortic involvement

 25-50

questions.text: Which of the following statement about phase reactions is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucuronide conjugation is the most common phase reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Phase II reaction makes the drug more water-soluble

options.label: C
options.text: Phase II reaction mostly catabolic reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Methylation is a phase II reaction

questions.correct_answer: C. Phase II reaction mostly catabolic reaction
questions.explanation:
Phase I reactions Phase II reactions
  • Mostly catabolic reactions
  • Includes
  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Cyclization
  • Deamination
  • Mostly anabolic reactions
  • Includes
    • Glucuronide [m/c phase reaction] conjugation
    • Glutathione conjugation
    • Acetylation
    • Methylation
    • Sulphate conjugation

questions.text: Which of the following is not asked in personal history in a psychiatric disorder?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The important components of personal history in psychiatry include the following: Perinatal history Childhood history Educational history (Academic history) Occupational history Sexual and marital history Menstrual history
  • ↳ The important components of personal history in psychiatry include the following:
  • ↳ The important components of personal history in psychiatry include the following:
  • ↳ Perinatal history Childhood history Educational history (Academic history) Occupational history Sexual and marital history Menstrual history
  • ↳ Perinatal history Childhood history Educational history (Academic history) Occupational history Sexual and marital history Menstrual history
  • ↳ Perinatal history Childhood history Educational history (Academic history) Occupational history Sexual and marital history Menstrual history
  • ↳ Perinatal history
  • ↳ Childhood history
  • ↳ Educational history (Academic history)
  • ↳ Occupational history
  • ↳ Sexual and marital history
  • ↳ Menstrual history
  • ↳ How to Remember: psychiatrists care about whether you have appetite or not but not what you prefer to eat initially.
  • ↳ How to Remember:

The important components of personal history in psychiatry include the following:
  1. Perinatal history
  2. Childhood history
  3. Educational history (Academic history)
  4. Occupational history
  5. Sexual and marital history
  6. Menstrual history

They also told that he started saying these kinds of things since last 4 months. What is your diagnosis?

A patient presented with a complaint of painful urination and abnormal discharge from the penis. On urine culture presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci were seen. Which of the following will be the drug of choice for this condition?
Which of the following are irreversible steps of the TCA cycle? SuccinateDehydrogenase Citrate Synthase α KG Dehydrogenase IsocitrateDehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Rate limiting enzymes of TCA cycle Irreversible steps of TCA
1. Citrate Synthase 1. Citrate Synthase (best answer)
2. Isocitrate Dehydrogenase 2. Alpha-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase
3. Alpha-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase

questions.text: A floppy child came with hypoglycaemia, hepatomegaly, and Cardiomegaly. This clinical picture is depicted by which enzyme deficiency?
